VAR is a statistical risk measure that summarizes returns into a single number, but whether it is superior to other risk measures is an ongoing discussion.

VAR summarizes the distribution of returns into a single number and is preferred over other measures because it has certain desirable properties for capital adequacy: Monotonicity (if portfolio 1 has systematically lower returns than portfolio 2, its risk is greater), Translation invariance (adding cash reduces risk by that amount), Homogeneity (increasing the portfolio size scales risk accordingly), Subadditivity (merging portfolios cannot increase risk).
Coherent risk measures satisfy four properties: monotonicity, translation invariance, homogeneity, and subadditivity; VAR fails to satisfy subadditivity due to issues with certain option positions.
